Chris James L.
Chris James L.
posts.content:
https://lnkd.in/gjwwh93f

1. Join iSocialize.me
2. Email you resume to
3. Schedule an interview.


iSocialize is a dynamic platform dedicated to connecting businesses with their customers through innovative e-commerce solutions. We’re on a mission to empower online and local businesses with tools that foster engagement and drive growth.
Job Description:
We are looking for enthusiastic and outgoing Brand Ambassadors to represent iSocialize. As a Brand Ambassador, you’ll play a vital role in promoting our platform, building relationships, and driving awareness of our services.
Key Responsibilities:
Promote iSocialize's mission, features, and benefits on social media and within your community.
Drive user sign-ups and engagement on the iSocialize platform.
Act as a point of contact for questions about iSocialize.
Provide feedback on customer experiences to help improve our services.
Attend virtual training sessions and team meetings as required.
Requirements:
Strong presence on social media platforms.
Excellent communication and networking skills.
Passion for connecting people and businesses.
Ability to work independently and manage time effectively.
Prior experience as a Brand Ambassador is a plus but not required.
What We Offer:
Competitive commission-based earnings.
Flexible working hours.
Opportunities to grow with a fast-moving company.
Exclusive access to iSocialize tools and resources.

posts.name:
Richard King
Richard King
posts.content:
Lots of people accuse me of being anti-remote….I’m not!!! 

In fact, here’s 101 REMOTE roles at!!!

PS the pandemic is over.

comments.commentText: "PS the pandemic is over." what's this about?

Aaron Vaders-Collins Mountains of data here: https://www.bls.gov/cps/telework.htm

And I’ve tracked the weekly job posts on LinkedIn for the past 60 weeks. I post every Friday. Remote crested 10% one time. Usually around 6-7%.

Richard King you’re assuming we aren’t about to see a wave of pandemics. We have an anti-science administration heading in to the White House next week and 4 potential pandemics currently brewing. Combine that with an administration bent on reducing corporate polishing restrictions and cutting down on medical funding and we’re in for a rough half decade.

Love remote!!!! It works for me. Natural introvert, mom of 3 teens. It keeps my life in check. People should have options that work for them. Times are different. Most families need multiple incomes. Having moms work in an office and take care of the house, kids etc like “normal” is unfair and exhausting!!! Remote saves our sanity.

posts.name:
Justin Endres
Justin Endres
posts.content:
3:15 am on my way to Riyadh. 

I got a call from an old colleague. Let's just say he was ready to throw his hands in the air with the org he works with. My advice was simple.

𝐃𝐨𝐧'𝐭 𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐭 𝐫𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐧𝐨𝐰—𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐭 𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐫𝐨𝐰. Execute today. Wake up and execute tomorrow. Keep quitting tomorrow. If you focus on executing today and quitting tomorrow --- you take back control, and that control begins to widen, making larger objectives possible.

Figured someone else might need to hear this. Adversity means you're in the fight. Let's roll!!!

comments.commentText: Sometimes you have to stay in the fight.

Chris Stinson Sometimes “staying in the fight” for your teammates is even more important than the mission itself. That “grit” that’s been ingrained in those who’ve made the sacrifice and extensive preparation.
the place to be !

posts.name:
Jeremy Spiegel
Jeremy Spiegel
posts.content:
Let's clear something up. There's a HUGE difference between what Mark Zuckerberg is doing, in cutting 5-10% of Meta's workforce, and HOW he's doing it.

Whether we like it or not, and many of us do not, the CEOs job is to maximize shareholder value.

If, by cutting the lowest performing individuals that helps bolster the bottom line and profit margins, he's doing his job.

Did he have to be so open about it?

Did he have to say it right after abolishing their DEI programs, and going on Joe Rogan's podcast to discuss how Meta "needs more masculinity?"

I'd have advised against that myself. But these leaders have neither had to be particularly self-aware, or accountable for their actions beyond those profits.

But make no mistake about it.

Managing people out, due to performance does NOT make a performance culture.

That's something you have to invest in. You have to believe and want your people to succeed. You have to have an environment and supportive culture that allows you to be the best version of yourself to perform.

But none of these companies have any interest in that.

They just want the performance without having to give anything back in return.

They could do better. They could do a lot better by their people.

They simply choose not to.

Work Hard. Be Kind. Let Good Things Happen!

comments.commentText:
The only place I take exception is in accepting that these people are truly low performers. Having been on both sides of layoffs, that is very often not the case. Performance assessments are heavily influenced by a manager's bias for certain individuals as well as particular demographics that the company wants to rid themselves of.

Companies frequently tell managers to come up with low performers - even if they are not - to meet a quota. You will also often see as part of a layoff demotions. They retain certain low performers due to the relationships those people have not based on their actual performance.

In my experience, those included in layoffs are predominantly in one of 3 camps:
- those with skills that have been deemed commodity or obsolete (even if that person is a very high performer)
- Individuals who have reported discrimination or harassment
- those in certain protected classes where this is a legal way to eliminate them. This includes higher paid older workers as well as women. Remote workers are also being targe nis point.

All of these are leadership failures.

Why people take the word of someone who has proven himself to be untrustworthy is mind boggling.

Tracey Scott late in 2023 I told my boss I was unhappy in my position due to changing nature of our work and the team. 

I KNEW then and there when the next layoffs would come around I’d be on the chopping block, and sure enough….

I’m not even mad about that bc again I was miserable, but it goes to show just how out in the open some people will be with less than compassionate behavior.

I was reorged under a Director who did not like me. When the reorg happened, my previous Director - truly one of the best, most ethical leaders and people I've ever met - fought the change but lost. The day he told me I said "I guarantee she will find a way to get rid of me." And she did. He fought that too but my fate was sealed.

I've been very outspoken about that layoff but it's not because of I'm bitter for my own sake. The environment was so toxic and unhealthy. It's because I loathe bullies and unethical behavior. I've fought them since I was a kid and have no tolerance for it.

I struggle with how readily people acquiesce and enable these behaviors. How few stand up for others the my previous Director did. It just ensures things will keep getting worse.

This right here is rotting America from the inside out: 

But these leaders have neither had to be particularly self-aware, or accountable for their actions beyond those profits.


You may be able to behave like a sh*t leader for a time and see better profits from cost saving, but it’s not a long-term, sustainable plan and eventually that will show in profits also. When your workforce thinks you’re a terrible human, they’ll never give you anything more than the minimum.

Maybe the minimum is 80 hours a week, but what will be lost is innovation, creative problem solving or doing anything outside of what is absolutely required to stay employed. So short sighted
Kelli M. T. she is-- she's an incredibly smart cookie that Heather Wallander

posts.name:
Matt Lakajev
Matt Lakajev
posts.content:
I rejected the CEO of a $423M company.

And it made me $400k. Here’s how:

In 2018, I hit rock bottom.

No job. No degree. No plan.

→ I applied for hundreds of roles
→ Only 2 gave me a shot and
→ One was a $423M giant.

The CEO sat across from me.

And said:

→ “You’re too good for this role”
→ “You’ll get bored”
→ “You won’t thrive”

They offered me the job.

I said no to.

Why?

Because I believed in Company B.

(before Covid)

I happily accepted their offer 

Then…

Zoom rejected me.

→ No job.
→ No income.
→ No clue what to do next.

But here’s where it changes.

→ A childhood friend worked there
→ We weren’t even close.
→ But I’d always been kind to him.

And he remembered.

→ He fought for me for months
→ He chased it to Zoom's CMO
→ He went out on a limb for me.

And weeks later, out of the blue

Zoom called me back.
They gave me the job.

→ That role changed my life.
→ Promoted 3 times in 3 years
→ Making $400k in commissions.

The lesson?

→ Trust builds over time and
→ Treating everyone with kindness
→ Compounds faster than Bitcoin.

And you never know what it will pay you.

Agree?

comments.commentText: You were meant for greatness! ️

Yash Kumar very kind of you! 

Have an epic weekend legend
Matt Lakajev You too!

posts.name:
Nat Berman
Nat Berman
posts.content:
Here's how hard Linkedin REALLY is:

Want to be one of the best on here?

Let's highlight some of the things I do on the regular

→ I literally comment for about 2-3 hours each day
→ This is every single morning when I post
→ I write 2 posts a day 4 days a week
→ I respond to nearly every DM
→ I dig into the analytics
→ It doesn't end

Is this easy? Yes and no.

→ I can comment like a machine.
→ Doing the work isn't like rocket science
→ Putting in the hours doesn't intimidate me
→ But it's taxing and grueling thus making it hard.

THIS is what it takes:

→ Writing targeted content
→ Engaging every day like crazy
→ Responding to every comment and DM
→ Doing the same stuff over and over and over
→ Getting ZERO results for a really really long time

On TOP of that?

→ You have to do it for YEARS, not months
→ You have to be nimble and adapt
→ You cannot be stubborn

And here's something else:

→ That's what it takes to grow your Linkedin account.
→ That's JUST a Linkedin account.
→ That's not my business

I still have community, client and sales calls.

Let's get something straight.

→ This is a CHOICE.
→ I take full responsibility.
→ I can easily work 2-4 hrs a day
→ Thankfully I've done well over the years

But if any of you are out there wondering why you aren't growing on here or in any other aspect of your life, check again.

Are you REALLY doing what it takes?

Chances are you are NOT.

If you want the real truth, stick with me, I won't hold back.

REPOST ️ to someone who needs to hear this

comments.commentText: If you are ready to do what it takes? Drop me a comment or DM and we'll talk about it.
Nat Berman wooooo

Great that you can do that Nat but I don't want to sit and comment for 2-3hrs - it's not a viable use of my time. It's not scaleable either. I can pay someone to comment for me or not. It's a bs game that we've been sucked into in my opinion. I'd rather spend money on targeted ads - doesn't take up my time and you can scale. I'm not criticising you at all. I just won't do what you've done.
Gav Gillibrand Is your business and life where you want it to be Gav? THAT's what matters.
Nat absolutely my man - always the right question.
